comments.text: Started raining and there was no cover but everyone going down there will be going to the very outskirts of the city like cikampek or further, so it‚Äôs super quick to get picked up. It‚Äôs just wide enough for two trucks, so if one pulls over u gotta run/communicate quickly
Solo guy caucasian. Hitchhiked there for less than 10 minutes with a sign ¬´¬†Cikampek¬†¬ª. Great spot to get out of Jakarta heading to the east, good luck ‚úåüèª

We walked from city center to here. It was only 1,5km from our hotel. This is the best spot as it is the exit to every road going towards Ruteng. 

It took us 15 minutes to hop on the back of a truck and we went straight from Labuan Bajo to Ruteng.

Be aware that many cars and mini vans will stop to offer you a shared taxi service. That is how it works for locals, they ‚Äúhitchhike‚Äù and pay what the driver ask. So just have your google translator ready with the explanation. 

The road was go

You can take angkot for 5k from the city to get to this place. Many small trucks are passing by, you can jump on one and get a lift in the back. We've changed 2 of them to reach Ruteng. Be aware, that minivans are mostly shared taxis. Make yourself clear before getting in.
If you going to Yogyakarta, so very easy point.
Pretty easy! A lot of trucks and cars going to Surabaya. However traffic is very slow.
this nice place for waiting some one pickup you...
the border is a great spot for catching lifts south.
Three cross in Sengon,place in Ngadiroyo,Nguntoronadi,Wonogiri
NGADIROYO VILLAGE

Some space to stop cars and trucks on the left after the ‚Äúcity gate‚Äù. Make sure to explain you want a free ride a ‚ÄúNUMPANG GRATIS‚Äù sign can help (‚Äúfree ride‚Äù). Many buses, taxis and so on but also trucks and private car. Found a direct ride to Atambua in 10min.
These rest areas are the best places to get big lifts, just wait for a truck and ask around. My old driver helped with the language barrier but even at 1am we found someone going to Bali
Banging spot, shade from sign (no rain cover tho). All trucks and cars going that way will use the tolls and go far/faster than 30km/h.
Same as last spot, just stand after the petrol station with a sign to get both lots of traffic. Had to ward of 3 taxi cars in the span of a few minutes but quickly got a lift down to a toll gate

Only took a few minutes, still had a big sign for cirebon so even the faster cars could see it and slow down. Stood just where the petrol station joins again so I could get both lots of traffic. Lift into Patrol for food then further to another petrol station

Super good spot as lots of trucks pull over here and stop. My last truck driver came with me and helped explain that I was hitching to the first Truckee talked to and they were going to Jakarta!!! Insane luck. I was interested to see Jambi, but with how slow the roads are here, I couldn‚Äôt pass up a ticket straight to Java.
Good spot to find a ride up north
Perfect spot to hitchhike towards Tumpak Sewu waterfall
Good spot to hitchhike toward Makassar
Ultra-super easy to get a quick ride from the ferry port to Banyu. I used a sign that said "Numpang Gratis," aka Free Lift.

If you get dropped off at the intersection and don't feel like walking to town, it's a solid spot to catch the last stretch. Many trucks are headed for Java, so you might even score a ferry ride. I got a lift to the port without even hitchhiking.

Lots of trucks & cars pass by this spot, heading to the ferry or up to the island's north shore. Easy catch, shouldn't take long at all. No shade here, so do yourself a favour and go early. I used a sign that said 'Numpang Gratis', aka Free Lift. Worked like a charm.

The spot's pretty out of Tabanan, and I ended up walking all the way here. I don't know, hitchhiking in the centre of Tabanan just felt kinda off. This spot was perfect tho‚ÄîI hitched a truck real quick heading west outta town. Loads of motorcycle traffic doesn't help, but try flagging down trucks specifically. Used a sign that said 'Numpang Gratis', aka Free Lift.
Hitching to Pangalpinang (back and fourt) is faster and more reliable then taking bus.
found a ride in direction of Padang quickly

Our ride was very kind and insisted we wait for the bus to Pacitan, that he would wait with us and flag the bus down, that it would be by any moment, and that nobody would pick us up.
They have very good intentions but avoid this kind of help at all costs. We waited, losing daylight, with lots of completely unintelligible googletranslate, until finally we were able to understand from him that maybe the bus would come in 45 minutes, and if not, then in 1.5 hours. Got a ride with a local family straight to Bima. In about 30-min driving along the road will be a shop called "susu kuda 88". Stop by and get some fresh horse milk. Such a nice flashbacks from Central Asia ;)
We had to walk a bit out from the city center. Easy to get a ride to Dompu or Bina.
Nice road with beautiful sceneries. Not much traffic which means you will get your ride pretty fast.
Many cars going nearby. We‚Äôve changed 3 cars until we got to Labuan Jambu. Many motorbikes on the road, so don‚Äôt expect be fast. But expect many friendly locals and a lot of fun.
We stayed here right after we got off the ferry, so there were many cars. Got a ride with a truck in 5 min.

We got a direct ride to Jakarta from here. To get to this spot from the city take a yellow minibus "ampera ‚Äî¬†karya jaya", it's shown on the google maps as well, and it's correct. Say the driver you need simpang kramasan. The only thing that after 5 minutes of standing there, the annoying cop appeared and wanted us to leave from this turn to the main road. We didn't do it though and just walked down away from him a little, he only seemed confused. Gladly we got our ride after a few minutes.

Towards Bangko, Jambi, and further. Pretty easy to hitch to this turn from the city. A few cars were passing by, but maybe the third one stopped for us and it was a family going all the way to Jambi. We dropped off at Sarolangun. Once again make sure you have no intention to pay beforehand. Although we spoke a lot with the driver about what we do and how we travel, In the end, the driver asked me to pay 400k for 2 people which seems a lot for such a ride, and I managed to bargain until 200k.
Got a direct to Padang Aro (near Kerinci mountain)

From here 3 of us got a direct ride to Pekanbaru. It was a 15-hour ride because the car broke at some point, and the road conditions were very poor. In the end, the driver expected a payment from us. I had no problem paying him some money for the petrol, etc, but if you are not willing to pay make sure to figure it out beforehand.

Easily hitched a truck to Sipirok. You can get out of the city by a local minibus for like 30 cents. Avoid stopping big trucks if you don't want to spend a lot of time. The road is narrow and going up and down.
This is a great spot to hitchhike towards Parapat and further. There were 3 of us and we got a crazy fast ride in the back of the truck almost all the way to Balige.
There were even three of us and still we hitch a truck to the giant abandoned fish seen in the Act of Killing movie. Not many cars, but works well in both directions.

Easy to get a ride to Kutacane or Ketambe, since there are just a few villages in between. We got a ride in 1 minute (once again!). There's also a gas station, so you can simply speak to the drivers there.

Few cars on this road. However, probably the first one will give you a ride. It took us 2 rides to get to Blangkejeren. The landscapes around are wonderful, looks like Siberia or something. People are polite and very friendly.
We didn't wait even a few minutes. Got a ride to Lumut from here.

From here we got a ride with the first car directly to Takengon, and stayed for a few days with a driver's family. Once again my only recommendation is to learn some basic Bahasa. People are very friendly and get to understand about hitchhiking quite easily when you explain them.

We hitch a local public van to get out of the city for just 1$. It brought us quite far, enough to cut off local traffic. Knowing some Bahasa will make things for you much easier. 

Lurus atau belok? ‚Äî¬†Straight or turn?
Ketika anda belok saya pergi ‚Äî When you turn away, I leave
Sedikit lurus ‚Äî a¬†little straight

At the bypass crossing of McDonald, i tried to hh to the airport. After saying no to 10 taxis and talking with a street food seller i managed to hitch a motorcycle, who went off to get a second helmet before giving me a ride. Had to wait about 30-40min.

Worth trying, but be prepared for many to stop and block other cars.
Big petrol station on the road to Bandul. Has a few restaurants which makes it a perfect place for a break.
I was just walking and showing my sign and a truck, that was going north, pick me up.  May be harder to hitchhike cars because there is a lot of local traffic
You can easily find some trucks that will go directly to Java

Just ask anyone at the market if they can take you to Koya where you can get on a 'taxi'-minibus for 7000 rupiahs (0,5euros approx). The taxi will drop you at Yotefa market in Abepura. Papuans are so helpful that they came towards me as soon as I crossed the border and found me a vehicule...
the end of the border village is a pretty decent hitching spot. gotta love papuans!
just take the minibus outside of the city and look for a ride :) in case you don t wont to take a mini bus

is really easy to find a truck just go close to the bus terminal and try to avoid all the people who will want to sell you a bus ride...just walk a little bit in your direction and wait for a truck :)
Decent spot to find a ride to the border, even if it is within the city we found a ride in 20min.

Had a sign for Pekanbaru, didn‚Äôt get much luck for an hour. The spot is pretty good, no shade in the day and no rain cover but there is a large spot to pull over. I was there late at night and was lucky enough to be under a street lamp. Took an hour (and 11 rejections of a lift to a bus station/directions to a bus stop) to get a lift.

Finally found a truck after 20 minutes. One lane and chaotic traffic but enough room for a truck to pull over. Super nice, took me out of this shit show and onto a straight clear road. 
 The spots no good if it‚Äôs raining but wou will get shade if it‚Äôs not midday.

We walked a bit through the town looking for a good spot and some shade, as we walked we tried to flag down cars direction Bali, and were lucky to get a ride to Semanu.
This road is mostly private cars, not many trucks (which is good, because the trucks are too slow)
Direction Bali. Small town, lots and lots of private vehicles. Not much place to stop, but we spoke to a car that was pulling out and through googletranslate got to Dlingo

We were standing near big mr.diy shop sign. Easy spot to get a ride to Lubuklinggau. But here once again the driver in the end asked to pay 100k, even though I asked him "apa gratis okay?" before getting in the car. So, say it out loud and a few times to make it definitely clear before you get in.

It was the first time when we waited more than 10 minutes in Sumatra. Probably the spot wasn't good enough, cars were passing by too fast to break, so we had to change a few spots until we finally made it. To get to this junction from Padang Pajang you can simply take the small local minibus for 5000 rupiah (the one with an open door). We got a direct ride to Alahan Panjang (Danau Diatas), and the driver invited us to stay at his place.

A lot of traffic, slow, not enough space to stop. In this spot all the different directions are possible.
There is a lot of cargo ships in Semarang, so you also have a lot of trucks coming and going to Jakarta and Surabaya
Yes

Only reason I was here was because my lift broke down. It‚Äôs on a toll road so cars and trucks are moving 80+. I had a big sign for Semarang tho and eventually a slower truck stopped and scooped me up before it got dark

Again this is technically on the route of the trucks (confirmed by another friendly local) but still heaps of local traffic. Good spot to pull over but people didn‚Äôt. Found another bike that took me 5 mins further

I was told this was the best spot to try and get out of the town. Sounded kind of dumb and might have been. The trucks do not go through the down, but rather down and along a backroad and rejoin towards Kerinci (sus my later points) which is probably why I was dropped here. It might be smarter (if possible) to get to the east side of the city and hope for a car or ute to take you to Kerinci, then try and get a car from there. I found most people were just confused and wanted to take me to the bu
Flag down a logging truck to get into the nearest town from Taman Nasional Kutai NP. No problem hitching. No money.

Our ride dropped us off at the bus station despite us trying to explain that we were hit hitchhhiking, and then they kept driving in the direction we wanted to go, jajaja. So we had to walk across town for 30 minutes. Narrow streets, but if someone wants to stop they will. People are confused, though, they've never seen hitchhikers and can't figure out what we're doing, they wave and smile at us bewilderedly, despite our sign saying "Numpang", which is like indonesian for "free ride". But sooner

The town is long, we had to walk a ways to get out of it. Narrow streets, but if someone wants to stop they will. People are confused, though, they've never seen hitchhikers and can't figure out what we're doing, they wave and smile at us bewilderedly, despite our sign saying "Numpang", which is like indonesian for "free ride". But sooner or later someone always stops.
There are lots of cool hidden jems to explore around Semanu if you have time and budget. Our ride took us to Kalisuci cave wher
Very few cars, maybe 1 every 5 minutes. But indonesians are very kind, so eventually someone stopped

Walked all the way from Kuta to here and is still far from the main road to Gilimanuk.
Is easy to stop cars, but all of them will ask you for money  (welcome to Bali) and everyone will tell you that no one will pick you up for free - just keep smiling and continue to say "gratis"... I waited about 30 to 40 min for a free ride (which is a lot for a western in Indonesia)
Hitching is not the done thing by Westerners... Told to take a 4 hour bus trip...
